msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.title: Summa Theologica, Prima Pars
msItem.incipit: Quia catholice ueritatis doctor non solum prouectos debet instruere
msItem.explicit: partus decebat eum qui est super omnia benedictus Deus in s. amen
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit prima pars summe fratris Thome de Aquino de ordine predicatorum
msItem.note: Over ‘fratris’ has been pencilled ‘sancti’. STO 4–5; Glorieux, Théol. 14ax.

msItem.title: An index of the tituli of the quaestiones and articuli.
msItem.note: The scribe corrects the text in the margins. Copious marginal annotation, especially at the beginning, much contemporary with the main text, some as late as s. xv.

supportDesc.extent:
264 (i + 263) leaves 325 230
245 160
The edges savagely retrimmed especially at the head, with loss of running heads and marginalia, and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: 1–2112, 2210; catchwords; quire-signatures of the usual late medieval form, often cropped.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of 42 lines. Running heads between lines ruled right across the page.

handDesc.handNote: An English gothic rotunda bookhand of university type, correcting its own work in the margins.

decoDesc.decoNote: On fol. 1 a 6-line initial Q in colours on a squarish ground, enclosing Thomas preaching to lay persons including a soldier, in the style of the William of Devon painter, for whom see E. Temple, ‘Further additions to the William of Devon group’, BLR11 (1984), 344–8 and figs 2–3; Morgan, Early Gothic, II, pp. 22, 128, 153, 161–2. Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Catchwords and runovers are associated with attractive grotesques in pen-and-ink.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, repaired in modern times; sewn on five bands; formerly chained from the usual position on the rear board; fols. i and 263 are modern paper blanks.

history.provenance: Doubtless made commercially in Oxford. In the outer margin of fol. 81 is a monk’s head very like the Gloucester ones illustrated by N. R. Ker, English Manuscripts in the Century after the Norman Conquest (Oxford, 1960), pl. 27 b-c. It is not known when this book came to the College prior to 1600.

Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with (1) ‘D. 4, 2’, s. xvii, canc., (2) the contents, s. xvii, (3) ‘N. 6. 6. Art:’, s. xvii, canc. and replaced with ‘I. 1. 2’, in red, and (4) the College bookplate. The James no. ‘6’ is at the head of fol. 1 (s. xvii in., slightly cropped), and the same number is inked on the foredge.
